ReviewList.Text: Although it was not as technical as I might have expected it to be, I thought the book did a good job explaining Einstein's theories in layman's terms.  Read this book if you have slight interest in the theory of relativity but do not wish to get into the advanced formulas or are not into physics.
If you want to learn a little about physics, this is a good place to start. It's a bit dry compared to a novel, but it explains how relativity works. I recommend it to everyone.

This book is great in two very important aspects:  It is fascinating in the work which  it explains in very good detail, and it is also easily understandable.  When I first bought this book I was afraid it might  be too hard  for me to understand, but as  I quickly found out it wasn't all that hard.  It goes into very good detail of the topic which it explains and uses easily understandable sentence- structure so you can understand what they're talking about.  I love this book and if you want to learn about Einstein's theory of Relativity, then get this book.  Great for anyone who wants to learn more about this topic.

This is supposedly an attempt to whittle down Einstein's Theory of Relativity to a layman's reading level.  This is not the case.  The language is very outdated and is not easily accessible to modern laypeople.  I have a background in physics and have a somewhat elementary understanding of most of Einstein's theories.  There are much more modern summaries of his theories available.
It is a good introduction to get your feet wet in Einstein's theory but it lacked any show of math which I found disappointing.

This slim book provides a discussion of the initial experimental confirmation of the Special Theory of Relativity from a calculations taken during a brief solar eclipse shortly after WWI.  This essay (for it is an essay and not a full-sized book) reminds us that before E = MC^2 became a well-known equation (the equation itself appears nowhere in this work) and before Einstein himself became well known, it was necessary to justify his complicated mathematics in order to account for the absence of the ether in Einstein's conceptions of the cosmos.  While it is strange to think that Einstein's works and the man himself were long obscure in the English speaking world, it is worthwhile that this work helped to familiarize the world of scientifically-inclined Englishmen and Americans to one of the most striking and notable thinkers of the 20th century.  Although not as interesting as the (translated) essay from Einstein himself, this is a worthy historical artifact as a work that introduced English speakers to Einstein before he was famous, at the very beginning of the time when he began to draw the attention of contemporary thinkers despite the fact that his daring was initially thought to be immensely eccentric.

Author.Name: atomicbohr
Author.Location: retired in St. Pete, FL, USA

ReviewList.Text: Good but complicated in the words used. Overall though, I didn't really like the explanations or the examples given by the author.
I read and try to keep facts in mind but need to study more physics to comprehend the terms.  Enjoyed the book.

H.A. Lorentz has made good attempt to make a concise statement about the theory of Relativity. But it appears to. Me that in making concise the  essential substance has been missed. First the division of chapters does not do justice to the main content of the theory. The basic points of the theory have not been made clear. We remain unaware of salient features of the theory after going through the book. But the book makes efforts to explain with some factual details and historical background this theory.
S interesting!!! I am 12.5 and I love learning about Einstein 's theories!! This book is easy to undtersand but at the same time does a GREAT JOB explaing this amazing formula!!!!!

This is quite good if you are looking for a high-level description of relativity without the mathematics. If you are looking for any math at all, look elsewhere. Overall, well written and clearly understood. I would recommend this.
I personally thought that this book was amazing it was a little hard to catch on to in the beginning but it got better and more interesting as the book progressed
A look into one of the greatest minds of the twentieth century. This book was a brief summary of Einstein's theory of relativity.
Interesting read, but disappointing.  I anticipated more formulas introduced on a layman's level.  I realize it was a classic, but I was not impressed.  I'm looking for more.
